ws.rocket.path

Class TreePath

  • java.lang.Object
    • ws.rocket.path.TreePath
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Iterator<String>

    public final class TreePath
extends Object
implements Iterator<String>, Serializable
    Represents a String-based path (to a tree node) enabling forward and backward iteration over path elements (segments). To construct this object, path as a String object must be given with the separator (unless default separator '/' may be used) for splitting the path into segments.

    Additionally, some constructors also enable path extension extraction by specifying extension separator (default is '.'). Allowed extensions may be given to restrict what is considered an extension. So when an unknown extension is met, it will remain unextracted from the last path segment.

    For more advanced extension tuning, a parsed path can be manipulated via setExtensionToSegment(boolean) by a path processor that recognizes that a valid extracted extension must still be part of the last path segment. When set to true, the getNext() method will return the last path segment together with extension, and getExtension() will return null.

    This class does not support modification of the underlying path, only iterating and printing out previous, following, and full path. Although this class implements the Iterator contract, it supports iterating in both ways (although, starts from the left).

    Note About Parsing

    When constructed from a path string using a separator, empty path segments between separators will be ignored. That includes path item separators at the beginning or end of the string. In addition, null and empty string as a path default to empty path.

    With regard to extensions, when there are multiple extension separators in the last path segment, only the last one counts. When there is no character after the extension separator, the last path segment will remain as it is. Otherwise, the extension will be removed from the path segment together with the separator. However, getExtension() method will return the extension without the separator.

    Navigating

    When iterating over path segments, a zero-based index can be retrieved via getPosition(). The total count of path segments is returned by getPathLength(). Methods hasNext() and hasPrevious() can be used for detecting whether navigating forward/backward is possible.

    Author:
    Martti Tamm
    See Also:

    • Constructor Detail

      • TreePath

        public TreePath(String path)
        Creates a new tree path iterator that uses default path item separator ('/') to extract path elements. This constructor does not attempt to identify a possible extension in the last path element.
        Parameters:
        path - The path string to iterate. A null value defaults to empty path.

      • TreePath

        public TreePath(String path,
        String pathSeparator,
        String extensionSeparator)
        Creates a new tree path iterator that uses given path item separator to extract path elements, and given extension separator to extract an optional extension from the last path segment. An empty separator (including null) value means no separator. Empty segments and empty extension will be skipped/removed from the outcome. When an extension is found, it will be removed from the last path segment, and made available through getExtension().

        This constructor does not place any restrictions on extensions, such as valid extensions or case-sensitivity. There are other constructors for that:

        • TreePath(String, String[], boolean), and
        • TreePath(String, String, String, String[], boolean).
        Parameters:
        path - The path string to iterate. A null value defaults to empty path.
        pathSeparator - The string to use for resolving path segments. May be null for no path segments.
        extensionSeparator - The string to use on last path segment for resolving a possible extension. May be null for no extension check.

      • TreePath

        public TreePath(String path,
        String[] allowedExtensions,
        boolean extensionCaseSensitive)
        Creates a new tree path iterator that uses default path item separator ('/') to extract path elements, and default extension separator ('.') for identifying an optional extension in the last path segment. Empty segments and empty extension will be skipped/removed from the outcome. When an extension is found, it will be removed from the last path segment, and made available through getExtension().

        This constructor enables more control over what can be considered an extension by accepting an array of allowed extensions, and a boolean indicating whether extension comparison is case-sensitive or not. When the array is null or empty, all kinds of extensions are allowed. Otherwise, the extension must be one of those in array. To disable extension evaluation completely, use either of constructors:

        • TreePath(String), or
        • TreePath(String, String, String) where extension separator is null.

        When extension matching is done in case-insensitive manner and the extension matches, the matching extension from the array will be returned by getExtension().

        Parameters:
        path - The path string to iterate. A null value defaults to empty path.
        allowedExtensions - An array of allowed extensions, or null.
        extensionCaseSensitive - A boolean that is true, when matching extension to values in the array must be case-sensitive.

      • TreePath

        public TreePath(String path,
        String pathSeparator,
        String extensionSeparator,
        String[] allowedExtensions,
        boolean extensionCaseSensitive)
        Creates a new tree path iterator that uses given path item separator to extract path elements, and given extension separator to extract an optional extension from the last path segment. An empty separator (including null) value means no separator. Empty segments and empty extension will be skipped/removed from the outcome. When an extension is found, it will be removed from the last path segment, and made available through getExtension().

        This constructor enables more control over what can be considered an extension by accepting an array of allowed extensions, and a boolean indicating whether extension comparison is case-sensitive or not. When the array is null or empty, all kinds of extensions are allowed. Otherwise, the extension must be one of those in array. (When extension separator is null, the array and the boolean parameters are ignored).

        When extension matching is done in case-insensitive manner and the extension matches, the matching extension from the array will be returned by getExtension().

        Parameters:
        path - The path string to iterate. A null value defaults to empty path.
        pathSeparator - The string to use for resolving path segments. May be null for no path segments.
        extensionSeparator - The string to use on last path segment for resolving a possible extension. May be null for no extension check.
        allowedExtensions - An array of allowed extensions, or null.
        extensionCaseSensitive - A boolean that is true, when matching extension to values in the array must be case-sensitive.

        public String previous()
        Returns the previous path element and moves the current path element cursor one position backward (if the iterator is not in the beginning of the path). Otherwise NoSuchElementException will be thrown.
        Returns:
        The previous path element.
        See Also:

        Provides the zero-based index of the current path segment. When path is created, this position is initially 0.
        Returns:
        An integer from 0 to getPathLength().

        Returns:

      • isPathEmpty

        public boolean isPathEmpty()
        Reports whether this path contains no path segments.
        Returns:
        A Boolean that is true when the path has no segments.

      • getExtension

        public String getExtension()
        Provides the extension that was extracted from the last path segment. May return an empty string when the last path segment ended with the separator. Returns null when no extension is present on the last path segment.
        Returns:
        A string with the extension, or null when it's not present.

      • getNext

        public String getNext()
        Returns the following path element (if the iterator is not in the end of the path) without changing the current path element cursor. Otherwise NoSuchElementException will be thrown.
        Returns:
        The following path element.
        See Also:
        hasNext(), next()

      • getPrevious

        public String getPrevious()
        Returns the previous path element (if the iterator is not in the beginning of the path) without changing the current path element cursor. Otherwise NoSuchElementException will be thrown.
        Returns:
        The previous path element.
        See Also:
        hasPrevious(), previous()

      • getPreviousPath

        public String getPreviousPath()
        Provides the (sub)path from the beginning of the path until the current path element (excluded).

        When the current position is at the beginning of the path or path is empty, the method will return an empty string.

        Returns:
        A String of the composed path.

      • getFollowingPath

        public String getFollowingPath()
        Provides the (sub)path from the the current path element (excluded) until the end of the path.

        * When the current position is at the end of the path or path is empty, the method will return an empty string.

        Returns:
        A String of the composed path.

      • getPathToCurrent

        public String getPathToCurrent()
        Provides the (sub)path from the beginning of the path until the current path element (included).

        When the path is empty, the method will return an empty string.

        Returns:
        A String of the composed path.

      • getPathFromCurrent

        public String getPathFromCurrent()
        Provides the (sub)path from the the current path element (included) until the end of the path.

        When the path is empty, the method will return an empty string.

        Returns:
        A String of the composed path.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:

      • beginning

        public TreePath beginning()
        Moves the path segment cursor (position) to the first path segment. This method does not alter the path itself.
        Returns:
        Reference to the current tree path instance.

      • end

        public TreePath end()
        Moves the path segment cursor (position) to the last path segment. This method does not alter the path itself.
        Returns:
        Reference to the current tree path instance.

      • append

        public TreePath append(TreePath suffixPath)
        Creates a new instance where the path will consist of this tree path and the suffix tree path (in this order). If this tree path contains extension, it will be discarded. The returned path will have the same extension as the suffix path. For this method to work, both tree path objects must use the same path separator, or a runtime exception will be thrown.

        This method will not alter the states of current and suffix tree paths.

        The returned path will have its path segment cursor at the beginning of the path.

        Parameters:
        suffixPath - The path to append to the current path.
        Returns:
        A new instance of tree path where the path is the sum of current path and suffix path. Its extension, path and extension separators will be derived from the suffix path.

      • isExtensionToSegment

        public boolean isExtensionToSegment()
        Reports whether this path instance will include the resolved extension as part of the last segment even if the extension was found and extracted. By default, this method will always return false, unless modified by setExtensionToSegment(boolean).

        When this method returns true, it means that in cases when extension was found, successfully validated, and extracted, the extension would still be appear as it were part of the last path segment (and getExtension() will return null).

        This is a feature enabling better handling of cases where extensions are expected and yet extension is also optional. Although, an extension may be valid, sometimes the extension may still be part of the resource name. For example, "data.json" may look as it were a name of file with data in JSON format. However, an application may figure out that it's just a bad name of a file with full name "data.json.pdf", which is possibly a binary version of the JSON data. In that case, the application may alter the isExtensionToSegment() property to remember that the extracted extension should actually be treated as part of the path segment name.

        Returns:
        A Boolean that is true when extension info is suppressed and extension will appear as the suffix of last path segment.

      • setExtensionToSegment

        public void setExtensionToSegment(boolean extensionToSegment)
        Alters whether possibly extracted extension should be treated as an extension or as the suffix of the last path segment. By default, isExtensionToSegment() is false.
        Parameters:
        extensionToSegment - A Boolean that is true when the extacted extension should be overridden and treated as suffix of the last path segment.
        See Also:
        isExtensionToSegment()
